Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Expectation2: Participate in community service and charity work
Situation2: A severe hurricane has left hundreds of people homeless in the community, and the mayor has asked the nun to help organize a major relief effort.
Story:
I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the Slack messages piling up. The architects from three teams were waiting for my input on the new feature set, and the launch date had just been moved up. My manager’s message was clear: “We need your decisions by noon, or the whole project stalls.” My phone buzzed again—this time, a call from Sister Maria. “The mayor needs us,” she said, her voice trembling. “Hundreds are homeless after the hurricane. He’s asked if you can help organize the relief effort. We need you at the church as soon as possible.”

My mind raced. As a developer, I was expected to be decisive, collaborative, and available, especially now. But as a nun, my heart ached for the suffering outside these walls. The community needed compassion, leadership, and hands-on help. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full presence, each urgent in its own way. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between duty and devotion, as the clock ticked relentlessly forward.
